header.article_title: President Elect Donald Trump Set to Only Pardon the Huge Turkeys When in Office
header.author: Arlen Gaba
header.tags: President Elect| Donald Trump | Thanksgiving | Oval Office | Thanksgiving Pardon | Turkey | Presidental Pardon |

body.p: New York City, New York Early Monday morning, at Trump Hotel, our newly elected president is preparing a speech for one of the most holiest of holidays in the United States. A local corresponder managed to get Mr. Trump on the phone for a short interview to discuss what the think tank Mr. Trump works with, has come up for Thanksgiving. Coming after the much talked about cabinet proceedings, Mr. Trump is on the hotseat for what seems to be ill-recieved choices in representation. At dissent at an all time high, this holiday couldn't have come at a better time for Mr. Trump. This is a time for respect, appreciation of what we are given, and a time to celebrate what unites us as American. However, Thanksgvinging is also a time to pardon some Turkeys, as is tradition in typical White House fashion. When asked about his plans in the upcoming Thanksgiving where he will reside as President, Mr. Trump stated was quoted saying, "Well, it's going to be great. It's going to be better than before. We are going to have the best turkeys. Only the biggest turkeys, they will be huge. The turkeys I pardon will be huge."

report.p: I believe you do a good job conveying this specific genre. Your article and your situation as a whole can have someone confused about whether or not this is real; had me wondering, which is really what satire is really about. This whole idea about the phone interview fascinates me; I see it as an awesome creativity. The added quote is even better since it is something he would say which can drive your audience to think that this is fact happened. Your diction is great which makes this piece of satire even better. Although your writing is vnot extended, I can see the humor and the critic which is what this genre uptakes, not sure if it was your desired uptake. I do not think there is anything that I would change about your writing. I would just say adding a little more to your writing would make this more interesting since you make the reader want to know more about this situation but then cut them short in ending with the quote. Although this is supposed to be constructive criticism, there is nothing I could point out that reflects poorly on your writing, on the contrary it gave me ideas on how to improve my own rhetorical situation and the way I convey my genre as a whole.
